question:
Given:
p1: Blue is a common color.
p2: Yellow is a common color.
p3: \sqrt{3}  is irrational.
p4: 5 is irrational.

Symbolize the following propositions:
(1) Blue and yellow are both common colors.
(2) Either \sqrt{3} or 5 is irrational.
(3) Exactly one of \sqrt{3} and 5 is irrational.

Specify that only &,||,~ can be used for this question.
Please format your answers as [[ ];[ ];[ ]], where each bracketed section contains the corresponding logical expression for each proposition.
needle: Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
title: Propositional Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "if p1, then p2" is represented as p1=::>p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 if and only if p2" is represented as p1=p2.
A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.
Formulas are represented using F1, F2, ..., Fn.
If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|✓,x|✓|✓ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

### Logic Rule:

Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.

Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 if and only if p2" is represented as p1=p2.
A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.
Formulas are represented using F1, F2, ..., Fn.
If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|✓,x|✓|✓ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

### Question:
Given:
p1: 4 is even.
p2: 5 is odd.

Symbolize the following propositions:
(1) Only if 4 is even, 5 is odd.
(2) If 4 is even, then 5 is even.
(3) Only 4 being even makes 5 even.
(4) 4 is even if and only if 5 is odd.
Please format your answers as [[ ];[ ];[ ];[ ]], where each bracketed section contains the corresponding logical expression for each proposition.

### Answer:
response:
To symbolize the given propositions using the specified logical rules and format, we follow the instructions provided.

1. **Only if 4 is even, 5 is odd.**
   - This translates to a logical implication where \( p2 \) implies \( p1 \).
   - The logical expression is: \( p2 =::> p1 \).

2. **If 4 is even, then 5 is even.**
   - This translates directly to a logical implication.
   - The logical expression is: \( p1 =::> \text{odd}(5) \), but since "5 is even" is not a proposition, we'll denote this as: \( p1 =::> \text{False} \).

3. **Only 4 being even makes 5 even.**
   - This is a bit tricky because it suggests a unique condition without specifying a logical structure. We infer it means \( 4 \) being even implies \( 5 \) being even.
   - The logical expression is: \( p1 =::> \text{odd}(5) \approx \text{False} \).

4. **4 is even if and only if 5 is odd.**
   - This translates to a biconditional statement.
   - The logical expression is: \( p1 = p2 \).

Therefore, the answers in the required format are:

```
[[p2 =::> p1];[p1 =::> False];[p1 =::> False];[p1 = p2]]
```

### Question:
Find the falsity values of the following formulas:
(1)~(~p1&p2)||~p3
(2)(~p2||p3)&(p1=::>p2)
(3)(p1=::>p2)&(~(p1&p3)||p1)
The answer format is [[F:...];[F:...];[F:...]].If there are multiple values in F, they should be separated by commas (,).For example [[F:x|x|x];[F:✓|✓|✓];[F:x|x|x,✓|✓|✓]]

### Answer:
response:
Given the logical rules and the propositions, let's identify the falsity values of the following formulas:

### Formula (1): \~(\~p1&p2)||~p3

We need to find the assignments that make this formula false.

1. \~(\~p1&p2) \(\rightarrow\) False when \~p1&p2 is True.
2. \~p1&p2 \(\rightarrow\) True when \~p1 is True and p2 is True.
3. \~p1 \(\rightarrow\) True when p1 is False (x).
4. p2 \(\rightarrow\) True when p2 is True (✓).
5. Overall, \~(\~p1&p2) is True unless \~\~p1 = p1 is False and p2 is True.

For \~(\~p1&p2)||~p3 to be False, both conditions must be False. Hence:

- ~p1&p2 \(\rightarrow\) True when p1 is False (x), and p2 is True (✓).
- ~p3 \(\rightarrow\) True when p3 is False (x).

Therefore, for \~(\~p1&p2)||~p3 to be False:
  - (p1 is True and p2 is anything)
  - or (p2 is False and p3 is True).

The assignments that make this False are:
- p1: ✓ , p2: x or ✓, p3: ✓.

Thus:
\[ \text{Falsity values for} \; \text{(1)} = [F:✓|x|✓, ✓|✓|✓]\].

### Formula (2): (~p2||p3)&(p1=::>p2)

For the formula to be False, one side of the conjunction must be False.

1. ~p2||p3 \(\rightarrow\) False when both sides are False
   - ~p2 \(\rightarrow\) False when p2 is True (✓).
   - p3 \(\rightarrow\) False when p3 is False (x).

2. p1=::>p2 \(\rightarrow\) False when p1 is True and p2 is False (✓|x).

Therefore, the falsity values include:

- p1: anything, p2: ✓, p3: x.
- p1: ✓, p2: x, p3: anything.

Thus:
\[ \text{Falsity values for} \; \text{(2)} = [F:✓|x|\_, ✓|✓|x, \_|✓|x]\] (where \_ can be anything since it does not affect falsity).

### Formula (3): (p1=::>p2)&(~(p1&p3)||p1)

For the formula to be False, one side of the conjunction must be False.

1. p1=::>p2 \(\rightarrow\) False when p1 is True and p2 is False (✓|x).

2. ~(p1&p3)||p1 \(\rightarrow\) False when both sides are False
   - ~(p1&p3) \(\rightarrow\) False when p1&p3 is True
     - p1 is True (✓).
     - p3 is True (✓).
   - p1 \(\rightarrow\) False when p1 is False (x).

Thus, for the whole formula to be False:

\[ \text{Falsity values for} \; \text{(3)} = [F:✓|x|\_, x|\_|\_],\] where underscores represent that the value of the second or third proposition does not matter.

### Answer:
\[ [[F:✓|x|✓, ✓|✓|✓];[F:✓|x|\_, ✓|✓|x, \_|✓|x];[F:✓|x|\_, x|\_|\_]] \]

So, the simplest result for expression (1) is:
\[ 0 \& r = 0 \]

\[ p \& (((p | q) \& !p) > q) = p \& (!((p | q) \& !p) | q) \]

Using rule (1): A ::=:: !!A
\[ p \& ((!p & !q) | !(!p) | q) = p \& ((!p & !q) | p | q) \]

\[ p \& ((!p & !q) | p | q) = p \& (p | q | (!p & !q)) \]

### Question:
According to the 16 Basic Equivalences, is the equivalence below valid? A. Yes B. No
(1) ((p>q)&(p>r))::=::(p>(q|r))
(2) !(p=q)::=::(p|q)&!(p&q)
The answer to each sub-question is a letter of the alphabet, and answers to different sub-questions are separated by ;.The answer format should be like [[A];[A]].

### Answer:
response:
To determine the validity of the given equivalences, we need to transform them using the basic equivalences provided in the logic rule.

#### For (1) \( ((p>q) \& (p>r))::=::(p>(q|r)) \)

1. **Translate the implication \( p>q \) and \( p>r \) using equivalence (10):**
   \[
   p > q ::=:: !p | q
   \]
   \[
   p > r ::=:: !p | r
   \]

2. **Combine the translations using and ( \& ):**
   \[
   (p > q) \& (p > r) ::=:: (!p | q) \& (!p | r)
   \]

3. **Distribute \& over | using equivalence (5):**
   \[
   (!p | q) \& (!p | r) ::=:: ((!p | q) & !p) | ((!p | q) & r)
   \]
   Simplifying further:
   \[
   ((!p \& !p) | (q \& !p)) | ((!p \& r) | (q \& r))
   \]
   \[
   (!p | (q \& !p)) | (!p \& r) | (q \& r)
   \]
   The term \(!p \& !p\) simplifies to \(!p\), so the whole expression simplifies to:
   \[
   !p | (q \& r)
   \]

4. **Translate \( p > (q | r) \):**
   \[
   p > (q | r) ::=:: !p | (q | r)
   \]

   The two expressions:
   \[
   !p | (q \& r)
   \]
   \[
   !p | (q | r)
   \]
   are not equivalent since \(!p | (q \& r) \) is not generally equal to \(!p | (q | r) \).

So, (1) is **false**.

#### For (2) \( !(p=q)::=::(p|q) & !(p&q) \)

1. **Translate the equivalence \( p = q \) using equivalence (11):**
   \[
   p = q ::=:: (p > q) \& (q > p)
   \]

2. **Use equivalence (10) for implications \( p > q \) and \( q > p \):**
   \[
   p > q ::=:: !p | q
   \]
   \[
   q > p ::=:: !q | p
   \]

3. **Combine the translations:**
   \[
   (p = q) ::=:: (!p | q) \& (!q | p)
   \]

4. **Apply negation using equivalence (6):**
   \[
   !(p = q) ::=:: !((!p | q) \& (!q | p))
   \]
   \[
   !(p = q) ::=:: !(!p | q) | !(!q | p)
   \]

5. **Simplify each term inside negation using equivalence (6):**
   \[
   !(!p | q) ::=:: p \& !q
   \]
   \[
   !(!q | p) ::=:: q \& !p
   \]

6. **Combine the results:**
   \[
   !(p = q) ::=:: (p \& !q) | (q \& !p)
   \]

7. **Compare with \( (p|q) & !(p&q) \):**
   \[
   (p | q) ::=:: p | q
   \]
   \[
   !(p & q) ::=:: !p | !q
   \]
   \[
   (p|q) & !(p&q) ::=:: (p | q) & (!p | !q)
   \]

   This is equivalent to:
   \[
   p & !p | p & !q | q & !p | q & !q
   \]
   Which simplifies to:
   \[
   0 | (p & !q) | (q & !p) | 0
   \]
   \[
   (p & !q) | (q & !p)
   \]

Since \(!(p = q)\) is indeed equivalent to \((p|q) & !(p&q)\), (2) is **true**.

### Conclusion:

\[
[[B];[A]]
\]

### Question:
According to the 16 Basic Equivalences, is the equivalence below valid? A. Yes B. No
(1) (p⇓q)⇓r::=::p⇓(q⇓r)
(2) (p⇑q)⇑r::=::p⇑(q⇑r)
The answer to each sub-question is a letter of the alphabet, and answers to different sub-questions are separated by ;.The answer format should be like [[A];[A]].

### Answer:
response:
To determine the validity of the given equivalences, we will use the defined Basic Equivalences and Propositional Symbolization Rules.

### Equivalence (1): (p⇓q)⇓r::=::p⇓(q⇓r)

First, let's expand the NOR operations using the rule (16):
- \( p \)⇓\( q \) ::=:: !\( p \) &\( !q \)
- \( q \)⇓\( r \) ::=:: !\( q \) &\( !r \)

Now, we apply these conversions:

\[
(\text{p} \)⇓\( \text{q}) \)⇓\( \text{r} ::=:: !(!p \& !q) \& !r
\]

\[
p \)⇓\( (q \)⇓\( r) ::=:: !(p \& !(!q \& !r))
\]

Next, we use De Morgan's laws and the double negation principle to simplify:

\[
!(!p \& !q) ::=:: p | q
\]

\[
!(!q \& !r) ::=:: q | r
\]

Substitute these into the expressions:

\[
(!(p | q) \& !r) ::=:: (!(p | q) \& !r)
\]

\[
!(p \& !(!q \& !r)) ::=:: !(p \& (q | r))
\]

Finally, applying double negations and De Morgan's laws:

\[
!(p \& (q | r)) ::=:: (!p | !(q | r)) ::=:: (!p | (!q & !r))
\]

Since the results are not equivalent, the equivalence (1) is not valid.

### Equivalence (2): (p⇑q)⇑r::=::p⇑(q⇑r)

First, let's expand the NAND operations using the rule (15):
- \( p \)⇑\( q \) ::=:: !\( p \) | !\( q \)
- \( q \)⇑\( r \) ::=:: !\( q \) | !\( r \)

Now, we apply these conversions:

\[
(\text{p} \)⇑\( \text{q}) \)⇑\( \text{r} ::=:: !(!p | !q) | !r
\]

\[
p \)⇑\( (q \)⇑\( r) ::=:: !p | !(!q | !r)
\]

Next, use De Morgan's laws and the double negation principle to simplify:

\[
!(!p | !q) ::=:: p & q
\]

\[
!(!q | !r) ::=:: q & r
\]

Substitute these into the expressions:

\[
(p & q) | !r ::=:: (p & q) | !r
\]

\[
!p | (q & r) ::=:: !p | (q & r)
\]

Since \((p & q) | !r\) is not equivalent to \(!p | (q & r)\), the equivalence (2) is not valid.

### Conclusion

Both equivalences are not valid. Therefore, the answers are:

\[[B];[B]\]

    - NAND is represented by `⇑`
    - NOR is represented by `⇓`
2. Basic Equivalences:
    (1) A ::=:: !!A
    (2) A ::=:: A | A, A ::=:: A & A
    (3) A | B ::=:: B | A, A & B ::=:: B & A
    (4) (A | B) | C ::=:: A | (B | C), (A & B) & C ::=:: A & (B & C)
    (5) A | (B & C) ::=:: (A | B) & (A | C), A & (B | C) ::=:: (A & B) | (A & C)
    (6) !(A | B) ::=:: !A & !B, !(A & B) ::=:: !A | !B
    (7) A | (A & B) ::=:: A, A & (A | B) ::=:: A
    (8) A | !A ::=:: 1
    (9) A & !A ::=:: 0
    (10) A > B ::=:: !A | B
    (11) A = B ::=:: (A > B) & (B > A)
    (12) A > B ::=:: !B > !A
    (13) A = B ::=:: !A = !B
    (14) (A > B) & (A > !B) ::=:: !A
    (15) A ⇑ B ::=:: !A | !B
    (16) A ⇓ B ::=:: !A & !B
3. Equivalence Calculation Rules:
    - The final expression should be completely represented using `|`, `&`, and `!`, without retaining `>` and `=`.
4. Truth Value Judgment Steps:
    - Define the practical problem to be judged as simple propositions and symbolize them.
    - Use simple propositions to express the formula based on each person's description.
    - Combine the information of who is true and who is false to write the final logical expression.
    - Use the above equivalences to derive and judge the truth of the expression.

### Question:
During a break at a seminar, three attendees tried to determine where Professor Wang is from based on his accent. Their statements were as follows:

Person A: Professor Wang is not from Suzhou, he is from Shanghai.
Person B: Professor Wang is not from Shanghai, he is from Suzhou.
Person C: Professor Wang is neither from Shanghai nor from Hangzhou.

After hearing these judgments, Professor Wang chuckled and remarked, "One of you got everything right, one got half right, and one got everything wrong."
Let p denote "Professor Wang is from Suzhou,"
q denote "Professor Wang is from Shanghai,"
and r denote "Professor Wang is from Hangzhou."

Exactly one of p,q,r is true, and the other two are false.
According to the rules stated, each person's statement should be represented using simple propositions.
Represent each person's statement:
Person A:!p&q
Person B:p&!q
Person C:!q&!r

Define the following logical expressions for Person A:

B1=!p&q (Person A's statements are entirely correct).
B2=(!p&!q)|(p&q) (Person A's  statements are partially correct).
B3=p&!q (Person A's statements are entirely incorrect).

Similarly, define the analogous expressions for Person B:
C1=p&!q.(Person B's statements are entirely correct).
C2=(p & q) | (!p & !q).(Person B's  statements are partially correct).
C3=!p&q.(Person B's statements are entirely incorrect).

And for Person C:
D1=!q&!r.(Person C's statements are entirely correct).
D2=(!q&r)|(q&!r).(Person C's  statements are partially correct).
D3=q&r.(Person C's statements are entirely incorrect).

According to Professor Wang's remarks, the final logical expression
E=(B1&C2&D3)|(B1&C3&D2)|(B2&C1&D3)|(B2&C3&D1)|(B3&C1&D2)|(B3&C2&D1)

After equivalent derivation according to the above rules, E finally simplify to
E::=::(!p&q&!r)|(p&!q&r).

Given that only one of p,q,r can be true, determine where Professor Wang is from. Who got everything right? Who got half right? Who got everything wrong?
Each choice should be selected from the three options provided.
Please provide the corresponding answers. The answer format should be:
[[Shanghai/Suzhou/Hangzhou]; [entirely correct: A/B/C]; [partially correct: A/B/C]; [entirely incorrect: A/B/C]].

### Answer:
response:
To solve this problem, we need to analyze the logical expressions given and apply the equivalences to arrive at the simplified form. Then, determine the truth values of \( p \), \( q \), and \( r \) based on Professor Wang's remarks that exactly one of \( p, q, r \) is true.

1. **Represent Each Person's Statement:**
   - Person A: \( !p \& q \)
   - Person B: \( p \& !q \)
   - Person C: \( !q \& !r \)

2. **Define the Logical Expressions for Each Person:**
   - For Person A:
     - \( B1 = !p \& q \) (Entirely correct)
     - \( B2 = (!p \& !q) \lor (p \& q) \) (Partially correct)
     - \( B3 = p \& !q \) (Entirely incorrect)

   - For Person B:
     - \( C1 = p \& !q \) (Entirely correct)
     - \( C2 = (p \& q) \lor (!p \& !q) \) (Partially correct)
     - \( C3 = !p \& q \) (Entirely incorrect)

   - For Person C:
     - \( D1 = !q \& !r \) (Entirely correct)
     - \( D2 = (!q \& r) \lor (q \& !r) \) (Partially correct)
     - \( D3 = q \& r \) (Entirely incorrect)

3. **Combine the Statements According to Professor Wang's Remarks:**
   - The final logical expression:
     \[
     E = (B1 \& C2 \& D3) \lor (B1 \& C3 \& D2) \lor (B2 \& C1 \& D3) \lor (B2 \& C3 \& D1) \lor (B3 \& C1 \& D2) \lor (B3 \& C2 \& D1)
     \]

4. **Simplify the Expression \( E \):**
   - Applying the equivalences, we simplify \( E \) to:
     \[
     E ::=:: (!p \& q \& !r) \lor (p \& !q \& r)
     \]

5. **Analyze Based on Exactly One of \( p, q, r \) Being True:**
   - If \( p \) is true (Professor Wang is from Suzhou):
     - \( p = 1 \), \( q = 0 \), \( r = 0 \)
     - Substitute into \( E \):
       \[
       E = (0 \& 0 \& 1) \lor (1 \& 1 \& 0) = 0 \lor 0 = 0 \text{ (not possible)}
       \]

   - If \( q \) is true (Professor Wang is from Shanghai):
     - \( p = 0 \), \( q = 1 \), \( r = 0 \)
     - Substitute into \( E \):
       \[
       E = (1 \& 1 \& 1) \lor (0 \& 0 \& 0) = 1 \lor 0 = 1 \text{ (possible)}
       \]

   - If \( r \) is true (Professor Wang is from Hangzhou):
     - \( p = 0 \), \( q = 0 \), \( r = 1 \)
     - Substitute into \( E \):
       \[
       E = (0 \& 0 \& 0) \lor (0 \& 0 \& 1) = 0 \lor 0 = 0 \text{ (not possible)}
       \]

Since \( E ::==:: (!p \& q \& !r) \lor (p \& !q \& r) \) is true only when \( q \) is true:
- Professor Wang is from Shanghai.

6. **Determine Who is Correct:**
   - Person A: \( !p \& q \) (Correct if \( p = 0, q = 1 \))
   - Person B: \( p \& !q \) (Incorrect if \( p = 0, q = 1 \))
   - Person C: \( !q \& !r \) (Incorrect if \( q = 1, r = 0 \))

Therefore:
- Person A is entirely correct.
- Person B is entirely incorrect.
- Person C is partially correct (since one part is true: \( !q \)).

### Conclusion:
\[
\text{[Shanghai]; [entirely correct: A]; [partially correct: C]; [entirely incorrect: B]}
\]

title: Disjunctive Normal Form and Conjunctive Normal Form
rule_content:
In a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) containing n propositional variables, if each propositional variable and its negation appear exactly once, and the propositional variables or their negations are arranged in ascending order of subscripts or in lexicographical order, such a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) is called a paired conjunctive term (paired disjunctive term).
If the true assignment of a paired conjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired conjunctive term is denoted as mi (lowercase m). If the false assignment of a paired disjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired disjunctive term is denoted as Mi (uppercase M). For example, the false assignment of ¬p∨¬q∨¬r is 111, and the binary number is 111, corresponding to hexadecimal number 7, denoted as M7.

- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes no paired conjunctive terms, A is a contradiction.

- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all odd, A is an all-odd formula.

### Question:
According to the above rules, what are the paired conjunctive terms of (¬p^¬q^r)∨(¬p^q^r)? How can this expression be denoted?

### Answer:
response:
First, let's identify the paired conjunctive terms of the expression (¬p^¬q^r)∨(¬p^q^r).

### Identifying Paired Conjunctive Terms

A paired conjunctive term must have each propositional variable and its negation appearing exactly once, arranged in lexicographical order.

For the term (¬p^¬q^r):
- ¬p appears once
- ¬q appears once
- r appears once

For the term (¬p^q^r):
- ¬p appears once
- q appears once
- r appears once

Therefore, both terms are already in the form of paired conjunctive terms as required by the rules.

### Determining the Hexadecimal Representation

Next, we need to find the corresponding true assignments in binary and their hexadecimal representations.

#### Assignment for (¬p^¬q^r):
- p = 0
- q = 0
- r = 1

So, the binary representation is 001, which corresponds to hexadecimal 1. Hence, this term is denoted as `m1`.

#### Assignment for (¬p^q^r):
- p = 0
- q = 1
- r = 1

So, the binary representation is 011, which corresponds to hexadecimal 3. Hence, this term is denoted as `m3`.

### Final Answer

The paired conjunctive terms of the expression (¬p^¬q^r)∨(¬p^q^r) are `m1` and `m3`. Therefore, the expression can be denoted as:

```
[[paired conjunctive terms: m1, m3]; [denoted: m1 ∨ m3]]
```

### Reference Format

```
[[paired conjunctive terms:...]; [denoted:...]]
```

rule_content:
Literal: A propositional variable and its negation are collectively referred to as literals.

Complement: If L is a literal, then the complement of L is denoted as L’. If L = p, then L’ = ¬p; if L = ¬p, then L’ = p.

Resolution: Suppose simple disjunctive clause C1 = C3 ∨ L, C2 = C4 ∨ L’, then C1 and C2 can be resolved, and it is defined that dispel(C1, C2) = C3 ∨ C4. If it is empty, then dispel(C1, C2) = 0.

Resolution Algorithm: The steps to determine if a conjunctive normal form has a satisfying assignment are as follows:
1. Input: Conjunctive normal form S.
2. Output: If S has a satisfying assignment, output “Plausible”; otherwise, output “Implausible”.
3. Steps:
    1. Initialization:
        - Let S0 and S2 be empty sets.
        - Let S1 be the set of all simple disjunctive clauses in S.
    2. Resolve clauses in S0 and S1:
        - For each simple disjunctive clause C1 in S0 and each simple disjunctive clause C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    3. Resolve clauses in S1:
        - For each pair of clauses C1 and C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    4. Check S2:
        - If S2 contains no elements, output “Plausible” and terminate the calculation.
        - Otherwise, add S1 to S0, set S1 to S2, clear S2, and return to step b.

response:
Let's apply the given logical rules to determine \( \text{dispel}(C1, C2) \) for \( C1 = \neg p \vee q \vee r \) and \( C2 = p \vee \neg r \vee \neg s \).

### Steps:

1. **Identify Literals and Complements**:
   - For \( C1 = \neg p \vee q \vee r \):
     - Literals: \( \neg p, q, r \)
   - For \( C2 = p \vee \neg r \vee \neg s \):
     - Literals: \( p, \neg r, \neg s \)

2. **Determine Compatibility for Resolution**:
   - \( \neg p \) in \( C1 \) can resolve with \( p \) in \( C2 \).
   - \( r \) in \( C1 \) can resolve with \( \neg r \) in \( C2 \).

3. **Resolution Process**:
   - Resolution of \( \neg p \) and \( p \):
     \[
     \text{dispel}(\neg p \vee q \vee r, p \vee \neg r \vee \neg s) = q \vee r \vee \neg r \vee \neg s
     \]
   - Simplifying by removing \( r \) and \( \neg r \):
     \[
     \text{dispel}(\neg p \vee q \vee r, p \vee \neg r \vee \neg s) = q \vee \neg s
     \]

   - Resolution of \( r \) and \( \neg r \):
     \[
     \text{dispel}(\neg p \vee q \vee r, p \vee \neg r \vee \neg s) = \neg p \vee q \vee p \vee \neg s
     \]
   - Simplifying by removing \( \neg p \) and \( p \):
     \[
     \text{dispel}(\neg p \vee q \vee r, p \vee \neg r \vee \neg s) = q \vee \neg s
     \]

### Conclusion:
Therefore, the result of \( \text{dispel}(C1, C2) \) is:

\[ [q \vee \neg s] \]

Hence, the answer in the required format is:
\[ [[q \vee \neg s]] \]

   \[
   S = (\neg p \vee q) \wedge (p \vee q) \wedge (q)
   \]

2. Extract all simple disjunctive clauses from S:
   - Clause 1: \(\neg p \vee q\)
   - Clause 2: \(p \vee q\)
   - Clause 3: \(q\)

3. Initialize sets:
   - \(S0 = \varnothing\)
   - \(S1 = \{ \neg p \vee q, p \vee q, q \}\)
   - \(S2 = \varnothing\)

**First Loop Iteration:**

**Step b: Resolve clauses in S0 and S1:**

Since \(S0 = \varnothing\), there are no clauses in S0 to resolve with S1.

**Step c: Resolve clauses in S1:**

- Clause 1: \(\neg p \vee q\)
- Clause 2: \(p \vee q\)
- Clause 3: \(q\)

We need to check pairs of clauses in S1 for resolution:

1. \((\neg p \vee q)\) and \((p \vee q)\):
   - Literal \(L = \neg p\) and its complement \(L' = p\).
   - Resolution:
     \[
     \text{dispel}(\neg p \vee q, p \vee q) = q \vee q = q
     \]
   - This clause \(q\) is already in S1, so it is not added to S2.

2. \((\neg p \vee q)\) and \((q)\):
   - There is no literal that can be resolved directly with its complement, so no resolution occurs here.

3. \((p \vee q)\) and \((q)\):
   - There is no literal that can be resolved directly with its complement, so no resolution occurs here.

Since no new clauses can be added to S2 from the resolutions, S2 remains empty.

**Step d: Check S2:**

Since \(S2 = \varnothing\), we would normally move to the next steps, but since S2 is empty, there are no new clauses to be resolved further.

**Conclusion:**

- Initial Sets:
  \[
  S0 = \varnothing, \quad S1 = \{ \neg p \vee q, p \vee q, q \}, \quad S2 = \varnothing
  \]

- S2 after the first loop iteration:
  \[
  S2 = \varnothing
  \]

Complement: If L is a literal, then the complement of L is denoted as L’. If L = p, then L’ = ¬p; if L = ¬p, then L’ = p.

Resolution: Suppose simple disjunctive clause C1 = C3 ∨ L, C2 = C4 ∨ L’, then C1 and C2 can be resolved, and it is defined that dispel(C1, C2) = C3 ∨ C4. If it is empty, then dispel(C1, C2) = 0.

Resolution Algorithm: The steps to determine if a conjunctive normal form has a satisfying assignment are as follows:
1. Input: Conjunctive normal form S.
2. Output: If S has a satisfying assignment, output “Plausible”; otherwise, output “Implausible”.
3. Steps:
    1. Initialization:
        - Let S0 and S2 be empty sets.
        - Let S1 be the set of all simple disjunctive clauses in S.
    2. Resolve clauses in S0 and S1:
        - For each simple disjunctive clause C1 in S0 and each simple disjunctive clause C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    3. Resolve clauses in S1:
        - For each pair of clauses C1 and C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    4. Check S2:
        - If S2 contains no elements, output “Plausible” and terminate the calculation.
        - Otherwise, add S1 to S0, set S1 to S2, clear S2, and return to step b.

response:

### Steps:

   - Let \( S1 \) be the set of all simple disjunctive clauses in \( S \):
     \[

     \]

2. **Resolve clauses in \( S0 \) and \( S1 \):**
   - \( S0 \) is empty initially, so there are no resolutions to perform in this step.

   - For each pair of clauses \( C1 \) and \( C2 \) in \( S1 \):
     - \( C1 = \neg p \vee q \)
     - \( C2 = p \vee q \)
     - \( dispel(C1, C2) = q \) (resolving \( \neg p \) and \( p \))
     - Since \( q \) is already in \( S1 \), it is not added to \( S2 \).

     - \( C1 = \neg p \vee q \)
     - \( C2 = q \)
     - These cannot be resolved (no complementary literals).

     - \( C1 = p \vee q \)
     - \( C2 = q \)
     - These cannot be resolved (no complementary literals).

     - \( C1 = q \)
     - \( C2 = p \vee q \)
     - These cannot be resolved (no complementary literals).

4. **Check \( S2 \):**
   - \( S2 \) contains no new elements.
   - Output "Plausible" and terminate the calculation.

### Conclusion:
The algorithm terminates in the first cycle since \( S2 \) remains empty after resolving all possible pairs. Hence, the conjunctive normal form is satisfiable.

\boxed{[\text{"Plausible"}; 1]}
\]

### Question:
For p∧(p∨q)∧(p∨¬q)∧(q∨¬r)∧(q∨r), 
what are S0, S1, and S2 before the second cycle of the resolution algorithm?
Provide the answers in the format [[];[];[]],
where sets are represented using {}, 
and an empty set is denoted by ∅.

### Answer:
response:
To determine the values of S0, S1, and S2 before the second cycle of the resolution algorithm for the given conjunctive normal form \( S = p \land (p \lor q) \land (p \lor \neg q) \land (q \lor \neg r) \land (q \lor r) \), follow the resolution algorithm steps as specified.

### Initialization:
- S0 is initialized as the empty set: \( S0 = \{\} \).
- S1 is the set of all simple disjunctive clauses in S: \( S1 = \{ p, (p \lor q), (p \lor \neg q), (q \lor \neg r), (q \lor r) \} \).
- S2 is initialized as the empty set: \( S2 = \{\} \).

### First Cycle of Resolution:

#### Step b: Resolve clauses in S0 and S1:
- \( S0 = \{\} \) (empty set) and \( S1 = \{ p, (p \lor q), (p \lor \neg q), (q \lor \neg r), (q \lor r) \} \).
- Since \( S0 \) is empty, no resolutions can be performed in this step. \( S2 \) remains empty.

#### Step c: Resolve clauses in S1:
- \( S1 = \{ p, (p \lor q), (p \lor \neg q), (q \lor \neg r), (q \lor r) \} \).
- Check all possible pairs of clauses in \( S1 \) to see if they can be resolved.

1. (p) and (p ∨ q):
   - Not resolvable.
2. (p) and (p ∨ ¬q):
   - Not resolvable.
3. (p) and (q ∨ ¬r):
   - Not resolvable.
4. (p) and (q ∨ r):
   - Not resolvable.
5. (p ∨ q) and (p ∨ ¬q):
   - Resolvable.
   - \( C = \text{dispel}(p \lor q, p \lor \neg q) = p \).
   - \( C = p \) is already in \( S1 \), so no need to add to \( S2 \).
6. (p ∨ q) and (q ∨ ¬r):
   - Resolvable.
   - \( C = \text{dispel}(p \lor q, q \lor \neg r) = p \lor \neg r \).
   - \( p \lor \neg r \) is not in \( S0 \) or \( S1 \), so add to \( S2 \).
7. (p ∨ q) and (q ∨ r):
   - Resolvable.
   - \( C = \text{dispel}(p \lor q, q \lor r) = p \lor r \).
   - \( p \lor r \) is not in \( S0 \) or \( S1 \), so add to \( S2 \).
8. (p ∨ ¬q) and (q ∨ ¬r):
   - Resolvable.
   - \( C = \text{dispel}(p \lor \neg q, q \lor \neg r) = p \lor \neg r \).
   - \( p \lor \neg r \) is already resolved in a previous step and added to \( S2 \).
9. (p ∨ ¬q) and (q ∨ r):
   - Resolvable.
   - \( C = \text{dispel}(p \lor \neg q, q \lor r) = p \lor r \).
   - \( p \lor r \) is already resolved in a previous step and added to \( S2 \).
10. (q ∨ ¬r) and (q ∨ r):
    - Resolvable.
    - \( C = \text{dispel}(q \lor \neg r, q \lor r) = q \).
    - \( q \) is not in \( S0 \) or \( S1 \), so add to \( S2 \).

After the first cycle:
- \( S0 = \{ p, (p \lor q), (p \lor \neg q), (q \lor \neg r), (q \lor r) \} \).
- \( S1 = \{ p, (p \lor q), (p \lor \neg q), (q \lor \neg r), (q \lor r) \} \).
- \( S2 = \{ p \lor \neg r, p \lor r, q \} \).

### Before the Second Cycle:
- S0: \( \{ p, (p \lor q), (p \lor \neg q), (q \lor \neg r), (q \lor r) \} \)
- S1: \( \{ p, (p \lor q), (p \lor \neg q), (q \lor \neg r), (q \lor r) \} \)
- S2: \( \{ p \lor \neg r, p \lor r, q \} \)

### Answer:
\[ [\ \{\}; \{ p, (p \lor q), (p \lor \neg q), (q \lor \neg r), (q \lor r) \}; \{ p \lor \neg r, p \lor r, q \}\ ] \]

For (p∨q)∧(p∨¬q)∧(¬p∨r), 
what is the output of the resolution algorithm?
How many cycles will it iterate? 
Please provide the answer in the format [[output];[number]].

### Answer:
response:
To determine the output of the resolution algorithm for the conjunctive normal form \((p \lor q) \land (p \lor \neg q) \land (\neg p \lor r)\) and the number of cycles it will iterate, we will follow the given resolution algorithm step-by-step.

### Step-by-Step Execution:

#### Initialization:
- Let \(S0 = \{\}\)
- Let \(S1 = \{(p \lor q), (p \lor \neg q), (\neg p \lor r)\}\)
- Let \(S2 = \{\}\)

#### Iteration 1:
1. **Resolve clauses in \(S0\) and \(S1\):**
   - \(S0\) is empty, hence no resolutions are possible.

2. **Resolve clauses in \(S1\):**
   - Pair 1: \((p \lor q)\) and \((p \lor \neg q)\)
     - Resolution not possible because there are no complementary literals.
   - Pair 2: \((p \lor q)\) and \((\neg p \lor r)\)
     - \(L = p\), \(L' = \neg p\)
     - \(\text{dispel}((p \lor q), (\neg p \lor r)) = (q \lor r)\)
     - \(C = (q \lor r)\)
     - Add \(C\) to \(S2\), as it is not in \(S0\) nor \(S1\).
   - Pair 3: \((p \lor \neg q)\) and \((\neg p \lor r)\)
     - \(L = p\), \(L' = \neg p\)
     - \(\text{dispel}((p \lor \neg q), (\neg p \lor r)) = (\neg q \lor r)\)
     - \(C = (\neg q \lor r)\)
     - Add \(C\) to \(S2\), as it is not in \(S0\) nor \(S1\).

#### Check \(S2\):
- \(S2 = \{(q \lor r), (\neg q \lor r)\}\)
- \(S2\) is not empty, so add \(S1\) to \(S0\), set \(S1\) to \(S2\), clear \(S2\).

Now, \(S0 = \{(p \lor q), (p \lor \neg q), (\neg p \lor r)\}\), \(S1 = \{(q \lor r), (\neg q \lor r)\}\), \(S2 = \{\}\).

#### Iteration 2:
1. **Resolve clauses in \(S0\) and \(S1\):**
   - Pair 1: \((p \lor q)\) and \((q \lor r)\)
     - Not resolvable.
   - Pair 2: \((p \lor q)\) and \((\neg q \lor r)\)
     - Not resolvable.
   - Pair 3: \((p \lor \neg q)\) and \((q \lor r)\)
     - Not resolvable.
   - Pair 4: \((p \lor \neg q)\) and \((\neg q \lor r)\)
     - Resolvable: \(\text{dispel}((p \lor \neg q), (\neg q \lor r)) = (p \lor r)\)
     - \(C = (p \lor r)\)
     - Add to \(S2\).

2. **Resolve clauses in \(S1\):**
   - Pair 1: \((q \lor r)\) and \((\neg q \lor r)\)
     - Resolvable: \(\text{dispel}((q \lor r), (\neg q \lor r)) = r\)
     - \(C = r\)
     - Add to \(S2\).

#### Check \(S2\):
- \(S2 = \{(p \lor r), r\}\)
- \(S2\) is not empty, so add \(S1\) to \(S0\), set \(S1\) to \(S2\), clear \(S2\).

Now, \(S0 = \{(p \lor q), (p \lor \neg q), (\neg p \lor r), (q \lor r), (\neg q \lor r)\}\), \(S1 = \{(p \lor r), r\}\), \(S2 = \{\}\).

#### Iteration 3:
1. **Resolve clauses in \(S0\) and \(S1\):**
   - Pair 1: \((p \lor q)\) and \((p \lor r)\) (Not resolvable)
   - Pair 2: \((p \lor q)\) and \(r\) (Not resolvable)
   - Continue with others...

2. **Resolve clauses in \(S1\):**
   - No resolutions possible.

#### Check \(S2\):
- \(S2\) remains empty.
- Since \(S2\) contains no elements, output “Plausible”.

### Conclusion:
The resolution algorithm outputs "Plausible" and iterates 3 times.

#### Answer format:
\([[\text{output}];[\text{number}]] = [[\text{Plausible}];[3]]\)

   - \( \land \) represents conjunction (AND), so we need two inputs \( p \) and \( q \).
   - \( \neg \) represents negation (NOT), so the entire conjunction \( p \land q \) is negated.

2. **Apply the given logical operations:**
   - First, evaluate the AND operation (\( p \land q \)).
   - Then apply the NOT operation to the result of the AND operation.

3. **Format the output:**
   - Use the notation \( [I, O] \) for each combination of inputs.
   - Represent the powered state as \( + \) and the not powered state as \( - \).

### Truth Table for \( \neg(p \land q) \)

| \( I1 (p) \) | \( I2 (q) \) | \( p \land q \) | \( \neg(p \land q) (O) \) |
|-------------|--------------|----------------|--------------------------|
| -           | -            | -              | +                        |
| -           | +            | -              | +                        |
| +           | -            | -              | +                        |
| +           | +            | +              | -                        |

### Formatted Answer:

```
[[-, -], +]
[[, +], +]
[[+, -], +]
[[+, +], -]
```

This represents the input-output mapping according to the logical expression \( \neg(p \land q) \).

### Question:

### Answer:
response:
To represent the logical expression \((p \wedge q) \vee (p \wedge r)\) in terms of a simple circuit diagram and truth table, we follow these steps:

1. **Identify the inputs**: The inputs are \(p\), \(q\), and \(r\).
2. **Determine the truth table for the expression**:
   - Create a truth table for all possible combinations of inputs \(p\), \(q\), and \(r\).
   - Calculate the output \(O\) for each combination according to the expression \((p \wedge q) \vee (p \wedge r)\).

Here is the truth table:

\[
\begin{array}{c|c|c|c}
p & q & r & (p \wedge q) \vee (p \wedge r) \\
\hline
+ & + & + & + \\
+ & + & - & + \\
+ & - & + & + \\
+ & - & - & - \\
- & + & + & - \\
- & + & - & - \\
- & - & + & - \\
- & - & - & - \\
\end{array}
\]

### Circuit Diagram:
The circuit diagram will have three inputs \(p\), \(q\), and \(r\). We need to implement:
- A conjunction (AND) between \(p\) and \(q\),
- Another conjunction (AND) between \(p\) and \(r\),
- A disjunction (OR) between these two results.

### Formatted Answer:
Following the provided notation:

\[
\begin{array}{lll}
[p,q,r, \text{O}] & [textual output depending on input states] & {description of input and output mappings} \\
\end{array}
\]

#### Truth Table Answered in Format:
\[
\begin{array}{lll}
[[p, q, r, \text{O}], & [+, +, +, +], & [textual description of states and output]] \\
[[p, q, r, \text{O}], & [+, +, -, +], & [textual description of states and output]] \\
[[p, q, r, \text{O}], & [+, -, +, +], & [textual description of states and output]] \\

[[p, q, r, \text{O}], & [- ,+, +, -], & [textual description of states and output]] \\

[[p, q, r, \text{O}], & [- ,-, -, -], & [textual description of states and output]] \\
\end{array}
\]

### Conclusion:
The simple circuit diagram corresponding to the logical expression \((p \wedge q) \vee (p \wedge r)\) can be depicted with an AND gate for \(p \wedge q\), another AND gate for \(p \wedge r\), and an OR gate that takes these two outputs as inputs. ### Question:
Assuming a simple circuit diagram 
corresponding to the logical expression (p∧q)∨(¬p∧r), 
with inputs I1 as "+", I2 as "-", and I3 as "+", 
what is the output? 
Please provide the answer in the format [[output]].

### Answer:
response:
To solve this problem, we need to evaluate the logical expression \((p∧q)∨(¬p∧r)\) given the inputs:

- \(I1 = +\) (which corresponds to \(p = \text{True}\))
- \(I2 = -\) (which corresponds to \(q = \text{False}\))
- \(I3 = +\) (which corresponds to \(r = \text{True}\))

Let's break down the expression step by step:

1. Evaluate \(p∧q\):
   - \(p = \text{True}\)
   - \(q = \text{False}\)
   - \(p∧q = \text{True} ∧ \text{False} = \text{False}\)

2. Evaluate \(¬p\):
   - \(p = \text{True}\)
   - \(¬p = \text{False}\)

3. Evaluate \(¬p∧r\):
   - \(¬p = \text{False}\)
   - \(r = \text{True}\)
   - \(¬p∧r = \text{False} ∧ \text{True} = \text{False}\)

4. Evaluate \((p∧q)∨(¬p∧r)\):
   - \((p∧q) = \text{False}\)
   - \((¬p∧r) = \text{False}\)
   - \((p∧q)∨(¬p∧r) = \text{False} ∨ \text{False} = \text{False}\)

Since the output is False, we represent it as "\(-\)" according to the given rules.

Therefore, the output \(O\) is \(- \).

So, the answer is \([[-]]\).

(2) If 5 is greater than 4, then 4 is greater than 6.

The proposition can be symbolized as?

For (2), define a binary predicate G(x, y): x > y. 
The proposition can be symbolized as?

Please provide the answers in the format [[];[]].
needle: Implication: Use ⇒

In general, a predicate P with n (n > 1) individual variables is called an n-ary predicate, denoted as P(x1, x2, ..., xn). When n = 1, P(x) denotes the property P; when n ≥ 2, P(x1, x2, ..., xn) denotes the relationship P among x1, x2, ..., xn.
Predicates without individual variables are called 0-ary predicates. For example, F(a), G(a, b), P(a1, ..., an) are all 0-ary predicates.
title: Predicate Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Universal Quantifier: Use Ax to denote "for all x".
Existential Quantifier: Use Ex to denote "there exists some x".

Logical Connectives:
Conjunction: Use &
Disjunction: Use |
Implication: Use ⇒
Negation: Use ∼

In general, a predicate P with n (n > 1) individual variables is called an n-ary predicate, denoted as P(x1, x2, ..., xn). When n = 1, P(x) denotes the property P; when n ≥ 2, P(x1, x2, ..., xn) denotes the relationship P among x1, x2, ..., xn.

Predicates without individual variables are called 0-ary predicates. For example, F(a), G(a, b), P(a1, ..., an) are all 0-ary predicates.

Let D be the domain of individuals.
"All x in D have property F" is symbolized as AxF(x).
"Some x in D have property F" is symbolized as ExF(x).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then x has property G" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ G(x)).
"Some x in D have both properties F and G" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & G(x)).
"For all x, y in D, if x has property F and y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as AxAy(F(x) & F(y) ⇒ H(x, y)).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then there exists some y with property G such that x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ Ey(G(y) & H(x, y))).
"There exists some x in D with property F, and for all y in D, if y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & Ay(G(y) ⇒ H(x, y))).

### Question:
In first-order logic, symbolize the following propositions using 0-ary predicates:
(1) Only 2 is a prime number, 4 is a composite number.
(2) If 5 is greater than 4, then 4 is greater than 6.

For (1), define a unary predicate F(x): x is a prime number. 
The proposition can be symbolized as?

For (2), define a binary predicate G(x, y): x > y. 
The proposition can be symbolized as?

Please provide the answers in the format [[];[]].

### Answer:
response:
For (1), the proposition "Only 2 is a prime number, 4 is a composite number" can be symbolized as:

\[ F(2) \sim F(4) \]

This means that 2 has the property F (prime number), and 4 does not have the property F.

For (2), the proposition "If 5 is greater than 4, then 4 is greater than 6" can be symbolized using the binary predicate G(x, y) to denote the relationship "x > y" as:

\[ G(5, 4) \Rightarrow G(4, 6) \]

This means that if 5 is greater than 4, then it implies that 4 is greater than 6.

So the answers are:

\[ [[F(2) \sim F(4)]; [G(5, 4) \Rightarrow G(4, 6)]] \]

### Question:
In individual domains limited to (a) and (b) conditions, symbolize the following two propositions:
(1) All humans breathe.
(2) Some people write with their left hand.
Where:
(a) Individual domain D1 is the set of humans.
(b) Individual domain D2 is the universal domain.

(a) 
Let F(x): x breathes.
G(x): x writes with their left hand.
In D1, apart from humans, there is nothing else,
thus (1) symbolizes as? (2) symbolizes as?

(b) 
In D2, besides humans, there are all things, 
so when symbolizing, humans must be separated first. 
Introduce predicate M(x): x is a human. 
In D2, clarify (1) and (2) as follows:
(1) For all individuals in the universe, if the individual is human, then they breathe.
(2) There exists an individual in the universe who writes with their left hand (or more precisely, there exists such an individual who is human and writes with their left hand).

Therefore, (1) symbolizes as?(2) symbolizes as?

Please provide the answers in the format [[];[];[];[]].

### Answer:
response:
Let's approach this step by step for both (a) and (b) conditions.

### (a) Individual domain D1 is the set of humans.

1. **All humans breathe.**
   - Let \( F(x) \) denote the property "x breathes".
   - Since the domain \( D1 \) includes only humans, the statement can be symbolized as:
     \[
     AxF(x)
     \]

2. **Some people write with their left hand.**
   - Let \( G(x) \) denote the property "x writes with their left hand".
   - The statement can be symbolized as:
     \[
     ExG(x)
     \]

### (b) Individual domain D2 is the universal domain.

1. **All humans breathe.**
   - We introduce the predicate \( M(x) \) to denote that \( x \) is a human.
   - For all individuals in the universe, if the individual is human, then they breathe:
     \[
     Ax \left( M(x) \Rightarrow F(x) \right)
     \]

2. **There exists an individual in the universe who writes with their left hand.**
   - More precisely, there exists an individual who is human and writes with their left hand:
     \[
     Ex \left( M(x) \& G(x) \right)
     \]

### Final Answer:

\[
[[AxF(x)]; [ExG(x)]; [Ax(M(x) \Rightarrow F(x))]; [Ex(M(x) \& G(x))]]
\]

In general, a predicate P with n (n > 1) individual variables is called an n-ary predicate, denoted as P(x1, x2, ..., xn). When n = 1, P(x) denotes the property P; when n ≥ 2, P(x1, x2, ..., xn) denotes the relationship P among x1, x2, ..., xn.

Predicates without individual variables are called 0-ary predicates. For example, F(a), G(a, b), P(a1, ..., an) are all 0-ary predicates.

Let D be the domain of individuals.
"All x in D have property F" is symbolized as AxF(x).
"Some x in D have property F" is symbolized as ExF(x).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then x has property G" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ G(x)).
"Some x in D have both properties F and G" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & G(x)).
"For all x, y in D, if x has property F and y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as AxAy(F(x) & F(y) ⇒ H(x, y)).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then there exists some y with property G such that x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ Ey(G(y) & H(x, y))).
"There exists some x in D with property F, and for all y in D, if y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & Ay(G(y) ⇒ H(x, y))).

### Question:
Using the domain of individuals as the set of real numbers R, 
symbolize the following proposition:
"For every ε > 0, there exists λ > 0 such that whenever |x - x0| < λ, it holds that |f(x) - f(x0)| < ε."

Let L(x): x > 0,
M(x, y, z): |x - y| < z,
N(x, y, z): |f(x) - f(y)| < z.

How can this be symbolized?

Please provide the answer in the format [[]].

### Answer:
response: [[Aε(L(ε) ⇒ Eλ(L(λ) & AxAx0(M(x, x0, λ) ⇒ N(x, x0, ε))))]]

title: Interpretation of Propositions
prompt:
You are an intelligent assistant that helps with various logical reasoning tasks. Below is a custom-defined rule for a specific type of logic. When responding, please ensure that your output adheres to the specified logical rules and format.

### Instructions:

1. Identify the relevant properties and objects as specified in the rule.
2. Apply the given logical operations or reasoning patterns.
3. Ensure your output is formatted according to the specified notation and symbols.

### Logic Rule:

The logical language 𝑀 consists of the following components:
1. A non-empty set of entities 𝐸;
2. Each entity constant a in 𝑀 has a corresponding entity a′ ∈ 𝐸, referred to as the assignment of a in 𝐽;
3. Each 𝑛-ary function symbol 𝑔 in 𝑀 has a function g𝐽, known as the implementation of 𝑔 in 𝐽;
4. Each 𝑛-ary predicate symbol 𝑅 in 𝑀 has a relation R𝐽, known as the implementation of 𝑅 in 𝐽.

Formulas 𝐵 under interpretation 𝐽:
1. Determine the entity set 𝐸;
2. Replace entity constants a in 𝐵 with a′;
3. Replace 𝑛-ary function symbols 𝑔 in 𝐵 with g𝐽;
4. Replace 𝑛-ary predicate symbols 𝑅 in 𝐵 with R𝐽.

The resulting formula is denoted as 𝐵𝐽, termed as the implementation of 𝐵 under 𝐽.

### Question:
(a) The non-empty set of entities E = natural numbers N.
(b) a′ = 2.
(c) Functions fJ(x, y) = x + y, gJ(x, y) = x * y.
(d) Predicate FJ(x, y) denotes x = y.

Write down the implementation of the following formulas under J:
(1) ∀xF(g(x,a),x)
(2) ∃xF(f(x,a),y)→∃yF(f(y,a),x)

Please provide the answer in [[];[]] format.

### Answer:
response:
To solve this problem, we will apply the given logical rules to the specified formulas. Below is the resulting implementation of the formulas under the interpretation \( J \).

### Given:
1. The non-empty set of entities \( E \) = natural numbers \( \mathbb{N} \).
2. \( a' = 2 \).
3. Functions:
   - \( f^J(x, y) = x + y \)
   - \( g^J(x, y) = x * y \)
4. Predicate:
   - \( F^J(x, y) \) denotes \( x = y \).

### Formulas to Implement:
(1) \( \forall x \, F(g(x, a), x) \)
(2) \( \exists x \, F(f(x, a), y) \rightarrow \exists y \, F(f(y, a), x) \)

### Implementation:

For formula (1):
- Replace constants and functions with their assignments and implementations:
  - \( g(x, a) \) becomes \( g^J(x, a') = x * 2 \)
  - \( F(g(x, a), x) \) becomes \( F^J(x * 2, x) \)
- Predicate \( F^J(x * 2, x) \) becomes \( x * 2 = x \)

Resulting formula:
\[ \forall x \, (x * 2 = x) \]

For formula (2):
- Replace constants and functions with their assignments and implementations:
  - \( f(x, a) \) becomes \( f^J(x, a') = x + 2 \)
  - \( F(f(x, a), y) \) becomes \( F^J(x + 2, y) \) which is \( x + 2 = y \)
  - \( f(y, a) \) becomes \( f^J(y, a') = y + 2 \)
  - \( F(f(y, a), x) \) becomes \( F^J(y + 2, x) \) which is \( y + 2 = x \)

Resulting formula:
\[ \exists x \, (x + 2 = y) \rightarrow \exists y \, (y + 2 = x) \]

### Answer Format:
[[ \forall x \, (x * 2 = x) ]; [ \exists x \, (x + 2 = y) \rightarrow \exists y \, (y + 2 = x) ]]

- Subject (S): The term in the proposition that denotes the object being discussed. Examples include "metals" in [1] and "products of labor" in [2].
- Predicate (P): The term in the proposition that denotes the property of the object. Examples include "conductive" in [1] and "commodities" in [2].
- Connectives(C): Words that connect the subject and predicate.
- Affirmative connective (e.g., "are"): Asserts that the subject possesses the property.
- Negative connective (e.g., "are not"): Asserts that the subject does not possess the property.

title: Propositional Logic Concepts
rule_content:
Direct Propositions:
Reflect propositions that assert whether something does or does not possess a certain property, also known as property propositions or subject-predicate propositions.

Examples:
- [1] All metals are conductive.
- [2] Some products of labor are not commodities.

Composition of Direct Propositions:
- Subject (S): The term in the proposition that denotes the object being discussed. Examples include "metals" in [1] and "products of labor" in [2].
- Predicate (P): The term in the proposition that denotes the property of the object. Examples include "conductive" in [1] and "commodities" in [2].
- Connectives(C): Words that connect the subject and predicate.
    - Affirmative connective (e.g., "are"): Asserts that the subject possesses the property.
    - Negative connective (e.g., "are not"): Asserts that the subject does not possess the property.
- Quantifiers(Q): Words that indicate the quantity of objects referred to by the subject.
    - Universal quantifier (e.g., "all"): Indicates all members.
    - Particular quantifier (e.g., "some"): Indicates at least one member.

Logical Forms of Direct Propositions:
- Universal Affirmative (A): All S are P, abbreviated as SAP.
- Universal Negative (E): No S are P, abbreviated as SEP.
- Particular Affirmative (I): Some S are P, abbreviated as SIP.
- Particular Negative (O): Some S are not P, abbreviated as SOP.
- Singular Affirmative: a is P.
- Singular Negative: a is not P.

Relationships: 
The relationships between declarative propositions are based on the premise that the subject and predicate are identical. 
This identity is referred to as having the same subject (S) and predicate (P). 
There are four types of relationships as follows:
- * Relation:
    - Between A propositions and O propositions, E propositions and I propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other is true.
- # Relation:
    - Between A propositions and E propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other may be true or false.
- & Relation:
    - Between I propositions and O propositions.
    - If one is false, the other is true; if one is true, the other may be false or true.
- % Relation:
    - Between A propositions and I propositions, E propositions and O propositions.
    - If the universal proposition is true, the particular proposition is true; if the particular proposition is false, the universal proposition is false.

- Definition: Change the quality of the original proposition (affirmative to negative or negative to affirmative) and replace the predicate of the original proposition with its contrary.

    4. Particular Negative Proposition (O): Some S is not P, can be converted to Some S is non-P.

Method B
- Definition: Exchange the positions of the subject and predicate of the original proposition to form a new proposition.
- Applicable Propositions:
    1. Universal Negative Proposition (E): All S is not P, can be converted to All P is not S.
    2. Particular Affirmative Proposition (I): Some S is P, can be converted to Some P is S.

Method C
- Definition: First perform obversion, and then perform conversion to transform the proposition.
- Applicable Propositions:
    1. Universal Affirmative Proposition (A): All S is P, can be converted to All non-P is not S.
    2. Universal Negative Proposition (E): All S is not P, can be converted to Some non-P is S.
    3. Particular Negative Proposition (O): Some S is not P, can be converted to Some non-P is S.

### Question:
Symbolise the following modal propositions:
"Science cannot be a one-man endeavour."

Use p to denote "Science is a human endeavour."
Please give your answer in [[]] format.

### Answer:
response:
To symbolize the proposition "Science cannot be a one-man endeavour" using the given notation, where p denotes "Science is a human endeavour," we need to identify the correct modal proposition that represents this statement.

The statement "cannot be" suggests a form of negation and impossibility. In modal logic, this is often represented using the necessity operator (#) along with negation (!).

Here's the step-by-step reasoning:

1. Identify the proposition:
   - p: "Science is a human endeavour."

2. Identify the negation of the proposition:
   - !p: "Science is not a human endeavour."

3. The statement "Science cannot be a one-man endeavour" implies that it is necessary that science is not just a one-man endeavour, which can be represented as:
   - #q, where q denotes "Science is not a one-man endeavour."

4. Given that "Science is a human endeavour" (p) is a more general statement, we interpret the provided statement as the necessity of the negation of a specific aspect of being a human endeavour (one-man endeavour).

Therefore, the modal proposition can be expressed as:

\[ \#!\text{q} \]

Where q stands for "Science is a one-man endeavour". This represents the necessity of the negation of science being a one-man endeavour.

Thus, the symbolized form of the given proposition is:

\[ [[\#!\text{q}]] \]

### Question:
Based on the truth modal reasoning formula 15, what can be inferred from "There is necessarily a connection between things"?

A. There is no connection between things.
B. There might be a connection between things.
C. There is a connection between things.
D. It is impossible for things to be connected.

Please answer in the format of [[A/B/C/D]].

### Answer:
response:
To determine what can be inferred from "There is necessarily a connection between things," we need to apply modal logic inference formula 15:

\[ p \rightarrow \$p \]

Let's denote the proposition "There is a connection between things" as \( p \). If we apply the formula \( p \rightarrow \$p \) to this proposition, it tells us that if \( p \) is true, then \( \$p \) (it is possible that \( p \)) must also be true.

The given statement "There is necessarily a connection between things" implies that \( \#p \) (it is necessary that \( p \)) is true.

Since necessity implies truth, if \( \#p \) is true, then \( p \) is true as per the inference \( \#p \rightarrow p \) (which is a commonly understood implication in modal logic).

Given that \( p \) is true and using formula 15 (\( p \rightarrow \$p \)), it follows that \( \$p \) is also true.

So, the correct inference is that "There might be a connection between things" because \( \$p \) means it is possible that \( p \).

Therefore, the answer is:

\[ [[B]] \]

(2) "Not protecting citizens' rights is allowed."
- This can be represented as ¬§p, where \( ¬p \) is "not protecting citizens' rights".

  - If p is "protecting citizens' rights", then ¬p is "not protecting citizens' rights".
  - Therefore, ¶p should be analyzed in conjunction with ¬§p to understand if it fits any relationship.

Using the normative reasoning formulas:
- Formula (8): ¬§¬p → §p

  - This indicates that §p and ¬§p cannot both be true (since ¬§p is the negation of §p), but they can both be false if there is no obligation or permission explicitly stated.

  - ¶p and §p both cannot be true and cannot be false according to the defined pair.

Thus, the relationship between ¶p and §p is a * relationship:

response:

   - Symbolized proposition: \( A p \)

   - Since the time period is left ambiguous (i.e., it could be an undefined past period of time), we use the symbol "H" to represent a past point in time.
   - Symbolized proposition: \( H q \)

### Answer:
\[[ \text{A p} ];[ \text{H q} ]\]

Thus, the propositions are symbolized as:
1. \( A p \)
2. \( H q \)

response:

   This can be represented as \(\neg A p\), where \(p\) is "Old Zhao worked in Ningbo."

- \(H\neg p\) can be inferred from \(\neg A p\).
- \(\neg A p\) can be inferred from \(H\neg p\).

Looking at the Time Proposition Inference Formulas, we find the following relevant formulas:

- \(A\neg p \leftrightarrow \neg H p\)
- \(\neg H \neg p \leftrightarrow H p\)
- \(H \neg p \leftrightarrow \neg A p\)
- \(H p \leftrightarrow \neg A \neg p\)
- \(\neg A p \leftrightarrow H \neg p\)

From these, we identify:
- \(H \neg p\) corresponds to \(\neg A p\).

- Common Belief (`G_p`): Indicates that the proposition `p` is a common belief within the group `G`, meaning all members collectively believe `p`.

    - Set of Worlds (`W`): All possible worlds.
    - Accessibility Relation (`R`): If `iRj`, it means individual `i` can recognize the belief state of individual `j`.

needle: Symbol Definitions:
- Belief (`B_p`): Indicates that an individual firmly believes the proposition `p` is true.
- Common Belief (`G_p`): Indicates that the proposition `p` is a common belief within the group `G`, meaning all members collectively believe `p`.

title: Epistemic Logic
rule_content:
Symbol Definitions:
- Belief (`B_p`): Indicates that an individual firmly believes the proposition `p` is true.
- Common Belief (`G_p`): Indicates that the proposition `p` is a common belief within the group `G`, meaning all members collectively believe `p`.
- Doubt (`H_p`): Indicates that an individual harbors doubt about the truth of the proposition `p`.

Cognitive Logic Model:
Cognitive logic simulates the interaction between different worlds and beliefs through the construction of models:
- Model (`M`): Composed of three parts:
    - Set of Worlds (`W`): All possible worlds.
    - Accessibility Relation (`R`): If `iRj`, it means individual `i` can recognize the belief state of individual `j`.
    - Truth Value Function of Propositions (`V`): Defines the truth value of each proposition in each world.

Definition of Common Belief:
If `p` is a common belief in the group `G`, then for every member `i` of the group, `B_ip` holds.

Cognitive Logic Axioms:

1. Basic Axioms
- Belief Axiom: `B_p → p`, indicating that if someone firmly believes `p` is true, it can be inferred that `p` is indeed true.

2. Advanced Axioms
- Axiom of Reflexivity: `B_p → BB_p`, indicating that if an individual firmly believes the proposition `p`, they also believe they believe `p`.
- Axiom of Transitivity: If `iRj` and `B_ip`, then `B_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` firmly believes the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` also believes `p`.
- Axiom of Consistent Belief: `B_p ∧ B_{¬p} → ⊥`, indicating that an individual cannot simultaneously believe in a proposition `p` and its negation `¬p`, as this would lead to a logical contradiction.

3. Axioms of Doubt
- Introduction of Doubt: `H_p → ¬B_p`, indicating that if an individual doubts the proposition `p`, they do not firmly believe `p`.
- Spread of Doubt: If `iRj` and `H_ip`, then `H_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` doubts the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` may also start to doubt `p`.

response:
To address the question using the specified logical rules, we need to consider the definitions and axioms provided.

\[ [ G_p \land H_a(p) ] \]

question:
Express using a logical expression that after executing the command sequence c1; c2, the proposition φ will necessarily be true.

needle: - Necessity Operator: `[ c ]φ` indicates that after executing command `c`, the proposition `φ` will necessarily be true.
title: Dynamic Logic
rule_content:
1.Symbol Definitions
- Command: `c` represents a basic operation within a program.
- Proposition: `φ` represents a statement or condition.
- Program State: Represents the system state after the execution of a command.

2.Dynamic Operators
- Necessity Operator: `[ c ]φ` indicates that after executing command `c`, the proposition `φ` will necessarily be true.
- Possibility Operator: `⟨ c ⟩φ` indicates that after executing command `c`, the proposition `φ` may be true.

3.Axioms and Rules
- Substitution Rule:If `c` behaves the same as `d`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `[ d ]φ`.
- Sequence Rule:`[ c_1; c_2 ]φ` is equivalent to `[ c_1 ][ c_2 ]φ`.
- Choice Rule:`[ c_1 + c_2 ]φ` is equivalent to `([ c_1 ]φ ∨ [ c_2 ]φ)`.
- Loop Rule:For the loop command `c*`, `[ c* ]φ` is equivalent to `φ ∨ ([ c ][ c* ]φ)`.
- Concurrent Rule:If `c_1` and `c_2` can be executed concurrently, then `⟨ c_1 || c_2 ⟩φ` is equivalent to `⟨ c_1 ⟩⟨ c_2 ⟩φ ∨ ⟨ c_2 ⟩⟨ c_1 ⟩φ`.
- Interruption Rule:If `c_1` can interrupt `c_2`, then `⟨ c_1; c_2 ⟩φ` is equivalent to `⟨ c_1 ⟩φ`.
- Exception Rule:If `c` may trigger an exception `e`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `([ c ]φ ∧ [ e ]φ)`.
- Resource Limitation Rule:If the command `c` is subject to resource limitation `R`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `(R ∧ [ c ]φ)`.
- Dependency Rule:If the execution of `c_1` depends on `c_2`, then `[ c_1 ]φ` is equivalent to `[ c_2 ][ c_1 ]φ`.
- Priority Rule:If `c_1` has higher priority than `c_2`, then `⟨ c_1; c_2 ⟩φ` is equivalent to `⟨ c_1 ⟩⟨ c_2 ⟩φ`.
- History Rule:If the execution of `c` depends on the historical command `h`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `[ h ][ c ]φ`.
- Prediction Rule:If the system can predict the outcome of `c`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `[ predict(c) ]φ`.

### Logic Rule:

1.Symbol Definitions
- Command: `c` represents a basic operation within a program.
- Proposition: `φ` represents a statement or condition.
- Program State: Represents the system state after the execution of a command.

2.Dynamic Operators
- Necessity Operator: `[ c ]φ` indicates that after executing command `c`, the proposition `φ` will necessarily be true.
- Possibility Operator: `⟨ c ⟩φ` indicates that after executing command `c`, the proposition `φ` may be true.

3.Axioms and Rules
- Substitution Rule:If `c` behaves the same as `d`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `[ d ]φ`.
- Sequence Rule:`[ c_1; c_2 ]φ` is equivalent to `[ c_1 ][ c_2 ]φ`.
- Choice Rule:`[ c_1 + c_2 ]φ` is equivalent to `([ c_1 ]φ ∨ [ c_2 ]φ)`.
- Loop Rule:For the loop command `c*`, `[ c* ]φ` is equivalent to `φ ∨ ([ c ][ c* ]φ)`.
- Concurrent Rule:If `c_1` and `c_2` can be executed concurrently, then `⟨ c_1 || c_2 ⟩φ` is equivalent to `⟨ c_1 ⟩⟨ c_2 ⟩φ ∨ ⟨ c_2 ⟩⟨ c_1 ⟩φ`.
- Interruption Rule:If `c_1` can interrupt `c_2`, then `⟨ c_1; c_2 ⟩φ` is equivalent to `⟨ c_1 ⟩φ`.
- Exception Rule:If `c` may trigger an exception `e`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `([ c ]φ ∧ [ e ]φ)`.
- Resource Limitation Rule:If the command `c` is subject to resource limitation `R`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `(R ∧ [ c ]φ)`.
- Dependency Rule:If the execution of `c_1` depends on `c_2`, then `[ c_1 ]φ` is equivalent to `[ c_2 ][ c_1 ]φ`.
- Priority Rule:If `c_1` has higher priority than `c_2`, then `⟨ c_1; c_2 ⟩φ` is equivalent to `⟨ c_1 ⟩⟨ c_2 ⟩φ`.
- History Rule:If the execution of `c` depends on the historical command `h`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `[ h ][ c ]φ`.
- Prediction Rule:If the system can predict the outcome of `c`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `[ predict(c) ]φ`.

### Question:
If Alice considers that executing the command c results in the library's open state being represented by the proposition open,

how would you express Alice's belief in logical terms?

response:

\]

This notation indicates that after executing command \( c \), it is certain (necessarily true) that the proposition \( \text{open} \) will hold.

title: Logical Methods for Exploring Cause and Effect Relationships
rule_content:
Five Methods for Exploring Causal Relationships

1. Method ⸮:
- If S and P occur together in multiple cases while other conditions A, B, C, E, F, etc., differ:
    - (1) S A B     P
    - (2) S C D     P
    - (3) S E F     P
    - ...
    - Therefore, S and P may have a causal relationship.

2. Method ؆:
- If P occurs when S is present and does not occur when S is absent:
    - (1) S A B     P
    - (2) - A B     P
    - Therefore, S and P may have a causal relationship.

3. Method ꙮ:
- Positive group: S and P occur together, while other conditions A, B, C, D, E, F, etc., differ:
    - Positive group
        - (1) S A B     P
        - (2) S C D    P
        - (3) S E F     P
    - Negative group: S is absent, P is also absent, and other conditions A, C, D, E, F, etc., differ:
        - Negative group
            - (1') - A C    -
            - (2') - D E    -
            - (3') - B F    -
    - Therefore, S and P may have a causal relationship.

4. Method ⵣ:
- When changes in S correspond to changes in P:
    - (1) S1 A B     P1
    - (2) S2 A B    P2
    - (3) S3 A B    P3
    - ...
    - Therefore, S and P may have a causal relationship.

5. Method ⚘:
- When S, A, B, C have causal relationships with P, X, Y, Z, and the causal relationships between A and X, B and Y, C and Z are known:
    - (1) A has a causal relationship with X
    - (2) B has a causal relationship with Y
    - (3) C has a causal relationship with Z
    - Therefore, S and P may have a causal relationship.

question:
In a class, 10 students were randomly selected to take a maths test and all got an A. According to the U-Generalization Rule, estimate the proportion of the whole class that would get an A if the class had 50 students.

Give your answer in [[number%]] format.
needle: - Definition: If a portion of the individuals in a sample possess a certain attribute, we infer that a certain proportion of the individuals in the population may possess that attribute.
title: Statistical Reasoning
rule_content:
1. Statistical Reasoning Categories and Symbolization

(1) U-Generalization
    - Symbol: `U`
    - Definition: If all individuals in a sample possess a certain attribute, we infer that all individuals in the population may also possess that attribute.

(2) P-Generalization
    - Symbol: `P`
    - Definition: If a portion of the individuals in a sample possess a certain attribute, we infer that a certain proportion of the individuals in the population may possess that attribute.

(3) C-Reasoning
    - Symbol: `C`
    - Definition: If two samples exhibit similarities in certain attributes, we infer that these two samples may come from populations with similar attribute proportions.

2. Statistical Attribute Inference Based on Samples

(1) Rule Description:
- Randomly select a representative sample from the population.
- Observe and record specific attributes of individuals in the sample.
- Depending on the frequency of the attributes and the type of sample, apply the following rules:

(2) U-Generalization Rule:
- If all individuals (denoted as `n`) in the sample possess attribute `A`, then we can infer that all individuals in the population also possess attribute `A`.
- Symbolization: If `U(A, n)`, then `∀x ∈ P, A(x)`.

(3) P-Generalization Rule:
- If `k` individuals in the sample possess attribute `A`, where `k < n`, then we can infer that approximately `k/n` proportion of the individuals in the population possess attribute `A`.
- Symbolization: If `P(A, k, n)`, then `Pr(A) ≈ k/n`.

(4) C-Reasoning Rule:
- If two samples S1 and S2 exhibit similar proportions in attribute `A`, i.e., `P(A, k1, n1)` and `P(A, k2, n2)`, then we can infer that these two samples may come from populations with similar proportions of attribute `A`.
- Symbolization: If `C(A, k1/n1, k2/n2)`, then `Pr(A, P1) ≈ Pr(A, P2)`.

### Question:
In a class, 10 students were randomly selected to take a maths test and all got an A. According to the U-Generalization Rule, estimate the proportion of the whole class that would get an A if the class had 50 students.

Give your answer in [[number%]] format.

### Answer:
response:
To apply the U-Generalization Rule, we follow these steps:

1. **Identify the relevant properties and objects:**
   - Sample size (n) = 10 students
   - Attribute (A) = getting an A on the maths test
   - Population (P) = the whole class of 50 students

2. **Apply the U-Generalization Rule:**
   - Given: All individuals in the sample (n = 10) possess attribute A (getting an A on the test).
   - Symbolization: `U(A, 10)`

3. **Formulate the inference:**
   - According to the U-Generalization Rule: If `U(A, n)`, then `∀x ∈ P, A(x)`.
   - Thus, we infer that all individuals in the population also possess attribute A.

4. **Estimate the proportion:**
   - Since the inference is that all individuals in the population possess attribute A, the proportion is 100%.

Therefore, the estimated proportion of the whole class that would get an A is:

\[ \boxed{100\%} \]

In the specified format:
\[ [[100%]] \]

### Question:
An air quality test was conducted in a city on 5 randomly selected days and it was found that 4 of the days had an air quality index (AQI) below 50.Using the P-Generalization rule, estimate the proportion of days in which the average AQI of the city was below 50. 

Please give your answer in [[number%]] format.

### Answer:
response:
According to the P-Generalization rule, if `k` individuals in the sample possess attribute `A`, where `k < n`, then we can infer that approximately `k/n` proportion of the individuals in the population possess attribute `A`.

In this case:
- Attribute `A` is having an AQI below 50.
- Sample size `n` is 5 days.
- Number of days with AQI below 50 `k` is 4.

Applying the P-Generalization rule:
\[ \text{If } P(A, k, n), \text{ then } Pr(A) \approx \frac{k}{n} \]

Substituting the given values:
\[ Pr(A) \approx \frac{4}{5} = 0.8 \]

Therefore, the estimated proportion of days in which the average AQI of the city was below 50 is:
\[ [[80\%]] \]

1. Statistical Reasoning Categories and Symbolization

(1) U-Generalization
    - Symbol: `U`
    - Definition: If all individuals in a sample possess a certain attribute, we infer that all individuals in the population may also possess that attribute.

(2) P-Generalization
    - Symbol: `P`
    - Definition: If a portion of the individuals in a sample possess a certain attribute, we infer that a certain proportion of the individuals in the population may possess that attribute.

(3) C-Reasoning
    - Symbol: `C`
    - Definition: If two samples exhibit similarities in certain attributes, we infer that these two samples may come from populations with similar attribute proportions.

2. Statistical Attribute Inference Based on Samples

(1) Rule Description:
- Randomly select a representative sample from the population.
- Observe and record specific attributes of individuals in the sample.
- Depending on the frequency of the attributes and the type of sample, apply the following rules:

(2) U-Generalization Rule:
- If all individuals (denoted as `n`) in the sample possess attribute `A`, then we can infer that all individuals in the population also possess attribute `A`.
- Symbolization: If `U(A, n)`, then `∀x ∈ P, A(x)`.

(3) P-Generalization Rule:
- If `k` individuals in the sample possess attribute `A`, where `k < n`, then we can infer that approximately `k/n` proportion of the individuals in the population possess attribute `A`.
- Symbolization: If `P(A, k, n)`, then `Pr(A) ≈ k/n`.

(4) C-Reasoning Rule:
- If two samples S1 and S2 exhibit similar proportions in attribute `A`, i.e., `P(A, k1, n1)` and `P(A, k2, n2)`, then we can infer that these two samples may come from populations with similar proportions of attribute `A`.
- Symbolization: If `C(A, k1/n1, k2/n2)`, then `Pr(A, P1) ≈ Pr(A, P2)`.

### Question:
A clinical trial of a new drug showed a positive response in 150 of 200 patients. Using the P-Generalization rule, the effectiveness of the drug in a wider group of patients was estimated.

Please give your answer in [[number%]] format.

### Answer:
response:
Using the P-Generalization rule, we observe that 150 out of 200 patients showed a positive response to the new drug. We can infer that approximately 150/200 of the wider group of patients may also possess this positive response.

The symbolization for this inference is:
\[ P(A, 150, 200) \]
Thus, the effectiveness of the drug in a wider group of patients can be estimated as:
\[ \Pr(A) \approx \frac{150}{200} = 0.75 \]

So, the answer is:
\[ [[75%]] \]

question:
The scientist observed that rats escaped whenever the lights in the lab were on. He proposes two hypotheses: 
(1) the rats escape because the light is on; 
(2) the rats escape because they hear a sound. 
If the light and the sound contradict each other, which paradox is this?

A. GB Paradox
B. BC Paradox
C. LS Paradox

Give your answer in [[A/B/C]] format.
needle: - Premise: An observed phenomenon p is noted.
- If hypothesis q_1 is assumed, then p.
- If hypothesis q_2 is assumed, then p.
- Since q_1 and q_2 are contradictory, they cannot both be true.
- Conclusion: In such cases, it is not possible to determine which hypothesis is correct, and further rules are needed to distinguish which inductions are reasonable.
title: Induction Paradox
rule_content:
1. GB Paradox

(1) Definition:
The use of the same observation to draw contradictory predictive conclusions through different inductive reasoning.

(2) Rules:
- Premise: An observed phenomenon p is noted.
- If hypothesis q_1 is assumed, then p.
- If hypothesis q_2 is assumed, then p.
- Since q_1 and q_2 are contradictory, they cannot both be true.
- Conclusion: In such cases, it is not possible to determine which hypothesis is correct, and further rules are needed to distinguish which inductions are reasonable.

(3) Symbolic Representation:
- p
- q_1 → p
- q_2 → p
- q_1 ∧ q_2 → ⊥

2. BC Paradox

(1) Definition:
The paradox that arises from the intuitive contradiction in the confirmation of a universal hypothesis through equivalence conditions and confirmation standards.

(2) Rules:
- Premise: Universal hypothesis ∀x(R(x)→B(x)).
- According to the confirmation standard, R(a)∧B(a) confirms ∀x(R(x)→B(x)).
- According to the equivalence condition, ∀x(R(x)→B(x)) is equivalent to ∀x(¬B(x)→¬R(x)).
- According to the equivalence condition, ¬B(b)∧¬R(b) also confirms ∀x(R(x)→B(x)).
- Conclusion: In such cases, care must be taken when determining the confirmation standards to avoid contradiction.

(3) Symbolic Representation:
- ∀x(R(x)→B(x))
- R(a)∧B(a)→∀x(R(x)→B(x))
- ∀x(R(x)→B(x))≡∀x(¬B(x)→¬R(x))
- ¬B(b)∧¬R(b)→∀x(R(x)→B(x))

3. LS Paradox

(1) Definition:
The paradox that arises when multiple hypotheses are reasonably accepted, and the logical consequence derived from these hypotheses contradicts another reasonably accepted hypothesis.

(2) Rules:
- Premise: Hypotheses r_1, r_2, ..., r_n are all reasonable.
- The logical consequence of these hypotheses, r_1 ∧ r_2 ∧ ... ∧ r_n, is also reasonable.
- If the conjunction of the propositions r_1 ∧ r_2 ∧ ... ∧ r_n contradicts hypothesis r_n+1, then the reasonableness of these hypotheses needs to be reassessed.
- Conclusion: In such cases, a balance point for the conditions of reasonableness needs to be found to avoid contradiction.

(3) Symbolic Representation:
- r_1, r_2, ..., r_n (reasonable hypotheses)
- r_1 ∧ r_2 ∧ ... ∧ r_n → Reasonable
- If r_1 ∧ r_2 ∧ ... ∧ r_n ∧ r_n+1 → ⊥, then reassess the reasonableness.

2. BC Paradox

(1) Definition:
The paradox that arises from the intuitive contradiction in the confirmation of a universal hypothesis through equivalence conditions and confirmation standards.

- Premise: Universal hypothesis ∀x(R(x)→B(x)).

- According to the equivalence condition, ∀x(R(x)→B(x)) is equivalent to ∀x(¬B(x)→¬R(x)).

- ¬B(b)∧¬R(b)→∀x(R(x)→B(x))

(1) Definition:
